but I feel a lot better now! Thanks!

Fujimaru 1:
Uh, I sure hope you're feeling better BECAUSE it's working!

Orion:
Just kidding!

Fujimaru 2:
Well, as long as you're feeling better, that's good enough!

Orion:
Hell yeah. Like they say, life only
goes in one direction: forward.

Goredolf:
Well? Do you think you can pull it off this time?

Orion:
Yeah, I definitely can.
Paris!

Paris:
Right!

Apollo:

This was more fun than I expected, humans.
Thanks.

Orion:
Artemiiis!

Narration:

His call rang out to the heavens like a lion's roar.

Narration:

Am I here right now because I'm a Grand Servant?

Narration:

Or because I'm the man who shot down a goddess?

Narration:

...I bet it's both.

Orion:
I renounce my Grand status so that I might finally shoot down Artemis, the moon goddess!

Holmes:
Renouncing your Grand status?
...Now I see!

Orion:
I won't let you fall for anyone else but me!

Orion:
Nobody else but me can wield this bow!
Nobody else but me can bring you down!

Orion:
I was summoned here of my own volition,
and I'm aiming my shot at you of my own volition too!

Narration:

Orion nocks the arrow, but the light of death that Mandricardo held back comes barreling towards him once more.

Narration:

He simply looks up at it and smiles a fierce,
indomitable smile.

Artemis:
I want to ask you something.

Orion:
What is it?

Artemis:
I acquired your memories from when you were alive and compared them to a recent scan of your brain.

Orion:
Hey, don't go peering into other people's memories!
Those are supposed to be private!

Artemis:
That other me–the Artemis you see in your world.
Why does she appear to be enjoying herself so much?

Orion:
Oh, that?

Artemis:
Yes, that.

Orion:
That's because yo–she's in love with me.
Least, I think so.

Artemis:
...

Artemis:
I don't know why, but that memory irritates me.
Would you mind if I took it?

Orion:
Uh, yes! Yes, I would!

Artemis:
...

Artemis:
How unpleasant.
Yet, unpleasant as it is, it's also fascinating.

Narration:
...That's right. You're broken.
You were broken long ago.

Narration:
You must've hit your limits forever ago.
You must've broken down ages ago.

Narration:
You've been drifting around the sky by yourself for ten thousand years, without anything to brighten your day.

Narration:
You could not even conceive of asking for help anymore, all because you're a goddess.

Narration:
I should have realized it sooner. I was a fool for refusing to do this, all because I didn't want to hurt you.

Narration:
...And you're a fool too,
for wishing you didn't have to hurt anyone.

Narration:
I think that's the key difference between you here and you in Proper Human History.

Narration:
All of you should've come down to Earth, even if it meant you'd end up hurting others or getting hurt yourselves.

Orion:
So get ready, Artemis.

Orion:
Because I'm about to hurt the hell out of you!

Narration:

He pulls back the string on the bow forged by a god.

Narration:

He draws back the golden arrow made by transforming a Heroic Spirit's body.

Orion:
You've been up there alone for too long, Artemis!
It's time you came down!

Narration:

The man who renounced his Grand status calls out to the goddess floating high above him.

Orion:
...Don't worry. I'll be right here falling with you.

Narration:

So many heroes gave their lives
so he could come this far.

Narration:

Francis Drake. Mochizuki Chiyome.
Charlotte Corday. Bartholomew Roberts.

Narration:

Achilles. Hektor. Mandricardo.
Paris. Apollo.

Narration:

All of their sacrifices were leading up to this moment!

Orion:
Noble Phantasm...

Narration:

His third Noble Phantasm is one that shouldn't even exist. It could only be achieved by a Servant renouncing Grand status, wielding a bow forged by a god, with an arrow made from a Heroic Spirit.

Narration:

An arrow he fires not out of hatred, nor conflict,
nor hostility, nor with the desire to kill...

Narration:
...with compassion, and love.

Orion:
Ortygia Amore Mio!!!

Narration:
A lone arrow, fired for the sole purpose of felling the moon goddess.

Narration:
Artemis soon realized there was nothing she could do to react in time. Neither intercepting the arrow, nor evading it, were plausible options.

Artemis:
Firing Shooting Star Ortygia.

Narration:
Even so, she chose to return fire.

Artemis:
(Why? Why? Why? Why?
Why is this happening? Why is this happening?)

Narration:
...I don't understand myself.
I don't understand this conclusion I've reached.

Narration:
I can't understand why he's doing this, either.
Why is he trying to kill me?

Narration:
Why did he break his oath in order to fight me?
Why did he aim his arrows at me?

Orion:
I figured it out.
I figured it out way back then!

Orion:
You weren't acting rationally when you blew up your terminal and the island she was on.

Orion:
You were acting emotionally.
You were angry...and jealous.

Orion:
Things you would never feel if you were just a machine!

Orion:
Which means these past ten thousand years
must have been unbearable for you!

Orion:
Did you really think I could stand seeing you
in such constant distress?

Narration:
The golden light tore through the
divine blast and kept sailing on.

Narration:
Orion's Noble Phantasm raced towards its destination with speed and power unlike anything the world had ever seen.

Narration:
It was an arrow created solely for Artemis.
An arrow fired out of his love for her.

Narration:
An arrow more powerful than anything. An arrow that would ignore all of Artemis's defenses, evade every unfair obstacle in its path, and find its way to her core with unfailing accuracy.

Artemis:
Ah–

Narration:
...I realized everything the moment it struck me.

Narration:
He truly had to put everything he had
into this arrow in order to fire it.

Narration:
This arrow is Orion's very essence, a Noble Phantasm
activated at the cost of his own life, all to destroy
the goddess of the moon.

Narration:
But in it there is not a trace
of animosity to be found.

Narration:
This arrow was kind, merciful, compassionate,
sorrowful, mournful, loving.

Narration:
This right here is the essential trait of Proper
Human History, and the crucial way we differ from it.

Narration:
This man–Orion–loved a god as his equal.

Narration:
It's a detestable fact. No god should ever fall,
especially at the hands of a human.

Narration:
And yet... And yet...!
Ahh!

Narration:
The moment I felt jealous
was the moment I truly lost.

Narration:
If I made all my separate units act independently,
and detached the ones that were destroyed...

Narration:
...I might still be able to stay in orbit,
and retain a minimum of viable firepower.

Narration:
But I can't. I can't do anything
now that I've taken this arrow.

Narration:
This arrow is pure love. Now that I've been struck,
there's nothing left but to fall for it.

Narration:
I know that Orion is from Proper Human History.
I know he fell in love with the Artemis of his world.

Narration:
I know it isn't actually me that he loves.
But, all the same...

Narration:
I was so happy that he cared enough to aim his love at me.

Artemis:
Hey. Why won't you join me in eternity?

Orion:
''Cause it'd be boring.

Artemis:
But death is so ugly and horrible.
Aren't you afraid of it?

Artemis:
If you became a god,
that would solve everything.

Orion:
I like the idea of ascending to the stars.
But no, becoming a god isn't for me.

Artemis:
Even though we could love each other for all of time?

Orion:
The day will come when we go our separate ways,
and our love comes to an end.

Orion:
It'll be sad when that happens,
but it's all part of being human.

Artemis:
Hmm. I don't get it.

Orion:
Well, of course you don't.
I mean no offense. It's just...

Orion:
You're a god. You have a different way of seeing the world. There's nothing wrong with that.

Orion:
But humans see–I see–the world differently. I think if I became a god, I'd regret it eventually.

Artemis:
But don't the prospects of eternal life and beauty sound appealing?

Artemis:
If you stay human, your body and soul will both grow old and feeble one day.

Orion:
Yeah, I might come to regret that too...
But, no, I'm pretty sure I'm good.

Orion:
Especially since, one day, the fact that I'm part of humanity might come to be pretty important.

Orion:
Though that's just a hunch.

Artemis:
So you're throwing away your chance at eternity on a hunch? What a horrible human you are.

Artemis:
But...that might be for the best.

Artemis:
Hey. If I ever need help as a god,
will you come save me as a human?

Artemis:
That's right.
You will, won't you?

Artemis:
You're an arrogant, foolish human,
overflowing with ridiculous sentiment.

Artemis:
That's all true...but it's also why it is so beautiful to me.

Artemis:
...All units...shutting down...

Artemis:
At last...I can finally...sleep...

Narration:
She feels herself falling apart. She was supposed to be indestructible, yet here she is, crumbling to pieces.

Narration:
The moon goddess falls to ruin not out of sin,
nor out of punishment...but out of love.

Fujimaru 1:
...Did you do it?

Orion:
...Yeah, I destroyed her. My part here is done now.

Orion:
I know it'll be hard for you to go on without me.
It'll be painful and sad, too. But even so–

Fujimaru 1:
We keep getting back up.

Orion:
Exactly, last Master of Earth.

Fujimaru 2:
We keep moving forward.

Orion:
There you go.

Orion:
Man... The sky really doesn't
belong to her anymore, does it?

Orion:
Part of me's gonna miss her,
but this is how it should be.

Orion:
I can't thank you enough, Master.
I couldn't have saved her without you.

Orion:
Oh...and one more word of warning.

Orion:
Grand Servants are usually summoned
for a really good, specific reason.

Orion:
So be careful, 'cause no matter what you run into, I won't be able to help you anymore. You see what I'm getting at?

Orion:
Hey, how 'bout one last handshake before I go?

Orion:
It's okay. There's nothing wrong with crying.
But don't spend your time looking back, either.

Orion:
All of history's made up of cycles repeating like that.

Orion:
Someday, you'll be passing the baton to someone else too, like Drake did.

Orion:
And when you do, you'll find you're the proudest you've been in your whole life.

Orion:
That's right. I'm real proud of you.

Orion:
No, not just you.
I'm proud of the whole of history that created you.

Orion:
After all, you picked up our baton and ran with it far enough for us to get here.

Orion:
I'm sorry I can't stick around till this is all over, but between you and Mash, I know you'll make do.

Orion:
All right then, get going to Olympus.
I've got a long overdue date with Artemis.

Fujimaru 1:
Goodbye, Orion.

Orion:
See you around.

Fujimaru 2:
Goodbye, Tri-Star.

Orion:
Hahaha, you're pulling out that name now?
Okay, it's a little embarrassing, but I'll take it.

Mash:
Orion...

Orion:
As for the rest of you at
Chaldea and the Wandering Sea...

Orion:
Make sure you really give it your all
as you back up Fujimaru and Mash here.

Holmes:

Orion:
Oh, and you there. Pudgy guy.

Goredolf:

Goredolf:
Wait, do you mean me!?
Who are you to comment on my physique!?

Orion:
Who else could I mean? Anyway, thanks.
You gave me the kick I needed to get back up again.

Goredolf:
Well of course! Any commander worth
his salt would have done the same!

Orion:
That went straight to your head, didn't it?

Goredolf:

Goredolf:

[♂ his /♀️ her] Command Spells because I ordered [♂ him /♀️ her] too.

Goredolf:

Orion:

Orion:

I'd end up disappearing all by my lonesome.

Orion:

with tears and laughter and good company.

Orion:

Orion:

From here on...it's all up to you!

Mash:

Nemo:

Nemo:

I'll put up the periscope's feed on the monitor.

Goredolf:
Well, I suppose it might be a little...
Hm?

Goredolf:

Holmes:
It's transparent.
...Just as I thought. It's a mirage.

Goredolf:

Goredolf:

Holmes:
Precisely. That Tree of Emptiness is an illusion,
and therefore impossible to cut down.

Mash:
Th-then what does this mean!?

Holmes:
The interstellar metropolis of Mt. Olympus does not exist in the sky. Quite the opposite.

Holmes:
It exists deep beneath Earth's surface!

Goredolf:
But...but the only way that makes any sense is if the hollow Earth theory were correct!

Goredolf:
And that nonsense was disproven ages ago!

Holmes:
Correct me if I'm wrong, but in an investigation I conducted earlier, I learned that there is also a great spirit graveyard deep beneath the Clock Tower, no?

Goredolf:
You mean the Spiritual Tomb of Albion!?

Goredolf:
Okay, yes, there is that, but come on!

Goredolf:
There's a big difference between the ground under the Clock Tower and a giant hollow in the middle of the Atlantic!

Holmes:

Holmes:
Apparently, it is even capable of tying a space that could normally never exist to reality.

Holmes:
In this Lostbelt, whatever lies down
that hole is the true face of reality.

Holmes:
This also explains why Kirschtaria's
domain is the most expansive.

Holmes:
Considering how we used magecraft to expand the Shadow Border's interior beyond its physical dimensions...

Holmes:
...it stands to reason that a Caster who excels at Territory Creation would be able to expand their domain.

Holmes:
That said, a feat like this is akin to turning Earth itself into an enormous container.

Holmes:
It truly is a display of power on a completely different scale.

Goredolf:
Th-then, cutting down the Tree of Emptiness we're seeing here would be–

Holmes:
Indeed. Meaningless.
As such, there is only one option available to us.

Holmes:
Instead of going up, we will have to go straight down into the Great Pit.

Holmes:
I expect that's also where we'll find Poseidon,
the last guard of Olympus!

Nemo:
We'll be diving down and heading towards that big hole, huh. Fine by me. That keeps things nice and simple!

Goredolf:
Whoa, whoa, easy there. Heading for the hole is all well and good, but we don't want to, you know, fall in, right?

Nemo:
I know that. Don't worry. I'll approach it slowly and circuitously so we can get a good idea of–

Nemo:
Khh... What the!? Th-there's an incredibly powerful gravitational force pulling us towards the Great Pit!

Goredolf:
There, you see!? What did I tell you!?

Nemo:
Quick! Head to the surface!

Holmes:
No, resisting will only put the Storm Border under unnecessary duress. As they say nowadays, I believe we should quite literally go with the flow here!

Nemo:
But what happens when we fall in the hole?

Holmes:
Don't worry. If I've read this right, and I believe
I have, then we won't fall to our deaths.

Holmes:
I believe this is Poseidon's
way of inviting us to see him!

Holmes:
Well, Commander? What do you say?

# Section 26: Final Showdown: The Hollow Sea God

Nemo Marine:
Our rate of descent's slowed down a bit now that we've submerged! But now there's a humongous whirlpool up ahead!

Nemo Marine:

Nemo:
Calm down. Just focus on keeping us steady and going with the vortex's flow.

Nemo:
All hands, keep to your posts!
Keep an eye out for hostiles!

Goredolf:
O-oogh, this is the worst turbulence I've ever experienced!

Goredolf:
Please tell me this will be over soon! I don't
think my stomach can take much more–Urp.

Nemo Professor:
Annnd there it is! We've got an enormous mass headed our way at one hundred knots!

Nemo:
All ahead flank! Evasive maneuvers!

Fujimaru 1:
A-are we okay!?

Nemo:
I need a damage report!
How's the engine!?

Nemo Engineer:
Aye, sir! Engine room here!

Nemo Engineer:
One of the main engines has been busted!
I'm gonna have to shut it down to fix it!

Nemo:
Got it.
Activate the secondary engines in the meantime!

Nemo Engineer:
Aye, sir! We should reach our top
speed in about twenty seconds!

Nemo Professor:
I just finished my analysis.

Nemo Professor:
This mass is composed of parts that are a sixty-three point eight percent match to those used in Artemis.

Nemo Professor:
So that, plus our current circumstances, lead me to conclude that it pretty much has to be Poseidon!

Nemo Marine:
It just came out of nowhere and slammed right into! Not the most sophisticated attack, but quite effective all the same! And here it comes again!

Nemo:
Load torpedo tubes one and two!
Let's bust this thing's head open!

Nemo Marine:
Aye, aye, Captain! Torpedoes are loaded and ready!

Nemo:
Fire!

Nemo Marine:
Yes, sir! Firing first and second torpedoes!

Nemo Professor:
Confirming two impacts!

Nemo Professor:
But it doesn't look like they had much effect!
The target's only getting closeeer!

Nemo:
Ready tubes three and four!
Get the others reloaded on the double!

Da Vinci:
Excuse me, can I say something!? Those last torpedoes
didn't actually hit! All they did was blow up!

Nemo:
...Explain.

Da Vinci:
I just told you. Those torpedoes didn't hit their
target at all. They just exploded right before they
reached it.

Da Vinci:
So I tried scanning further down...

Da Vinci:
...and I found a ridiculously strong magical
energy barrier shrouding that thing.

Da Vinci:
That barrier is powered by four–Uh,
three highly dense energy sources.

Da Vinci:
And when I say highly dense, I mean each one
has Holy Grail levels of magical energy.

Da Vinci:
I thought they looked familiar, and I finally
remembered why. They're the same as this.

Jason:
Right! That thing Drake took from Poseidon!

Da Vinci:
Exactly. A Poseidon core.

Da Vinci:
That magical energy barrier is supposed to be powered by all four cores, but now that one core is missing thanks to Drake, it's left a noticeable hole.

Nemo:
Professor, reanalyze our offensive options with this new information in mind!

Nemo Professor:
On it.

Nemo Professor:
Da Vinci is right. I'm reading a gap in the defensive barrier toward Poseidon's aft quarter.

Nemo Professor:
It's clear we'll have to make use of
this gaping hole in our strategy.

Goredolf:
I know! We could shoot a bunch of torpedoes into it!

Nemo:
...No, that won't work.

Nemo:
Even if we fired every last torpedo we have in there, it would only destroy his back.

Nemo:
Remember what happened with Artemis.

Nemo:
These things won't stop unless we completely destroy their weak points.

Nemo:
In Poseidon's case, that means we'll have to destroy the other cores.

Jason:
Whoa, whoa, whoa, what are you saying?
Do you even hear yourself?

Jason:
We might know that Poseidon's weak points are these cores, but those cores are all being protected by this impenetrable magical energy barrier.

Jason:
So how can we destroy the cores
and get rid of the barrier...

Jason:
...when that same barrier is preventing us from destroying the cores?

Jason:
There's nothing we can do. It's hopeless.

Nemo:
That logic's as circular as a school of pilchard...but it's not wrong.

Holmes:
...Now I see.

Holmes:
Once again, it appears we owe
Francis Drake a great debt indeed.

Goredolf:
Hm? What are you talking about, Holmes?

Holmes:
While I'm afraid she took her
methods to the grave with her...

Holmes:

Holmes:

Goredolf:

Jason:

Goredolf & Jason:

Holmes:

Nemo:

Nemo:
But are you aware of just how dangerous this operation would be, Holmes?

Holmes:

Holmes:
But, it is far from impossible.
Besides, it's the only option we've got.

Nemo:

In war, death is an inevitability.

Nemo:

Nemo:
In this case, that would be me–my ship running aground, followed by the soldiers disembarking from it.

Nemo:

Captain...

I refuse to let that happen!

General quarters! All hands, brace!

Nemo:

We're going to fight collisions with collisions!

Mo–Kill. Kill. Kill. Kill, kill, kill. Kill her dead. Incinerate her. Leave no trace of her corpse behind.

Mash:
...!

Fujimaru 1:
Are you okay!?

Mash:
I'm fine! The Ortinax is still good to go!

Fujimaru 1:
They really are focusing on you...

Holmes:
I expect Poseidon's estimation of your threat level has gone up considerably now that you've destroyed one of his cores.

Holmes:
I advise you to keep that in mind, and to expect that the next core will be even more difficult than the last.

Mash:
Understood!
Let's go, Master!

P.A. System:
Initiating defenses. Initiating defenses.
Target: Francis Drake.

--BATTLE--

Goredolf:
There! We're almost to the last core!

Meunière:
Just so you're aware, we've been getting an endless string of identical warnings for a while now!

P.A. System:
Capture Francis Drake at all costs.

Goredolf:
How can such a machine make a mistake like this!?

Holmes:
It just goes to show that computer bugs can strike anywhere.

Goredolf:
All right, that's as close as I can get!

Fujimaru 1:
Thanks, Director! We'll take it from here!

E：Mash:
Let's go, Master!

Da Vinci:
I can sense even stronger energy coming from that core compared to the others.

Da Vinci:
Watch your ste–
Wait! Servant readings incoming!

Mash:
You're...

P.A. System:
Drake... Francis Drake...

???:
This is the true face of Poseidon: a factory ship designed to renovate planetary environments.

???:
His primary objective was the renovation and oversight of marine environments.

???:
Though of course, as you can see, he's now nothing more than the Great Pit's guard.

???:
That said, he still had some semblance of sanity remaining. Right up until Drake took one of his cores.

Fujimaru 1:
Chiron...!

Chiron:
How good to see you again, Master of Proper Human History.

Jason:
...Chiron.

Chiron:
Oh, I'm surprised to see you're still alive, Jason.
Well, no matter.

Chiron:
The fact remains, I am the last soldier tasked with defending the Sea of Atlantis.

Jason:
Achilles really handed your horse ass to you, didn't he? From what I hear, not even dying was enough to stop him giving you a hard time.

Chiron:
Indeed, it was quite the embarrassing spectacle.

Chiron:
Regardless, this is still the last bastion between you and Olympus. Neither of us have the luxury of turning back now, even if we wished to.

Chiron:
And while we're on the subject...

Chiron:
Let us not forget that I killed Achilles,
and you lot killed Odysseus.

Jason:
So what, you're saying we're even now?

Chiron:
Hardly.

Chiron:
I'm saying that any chance we may have had for a peaceful reconciliation is long gone.

Chiron:
I am Chiron.

Chiron:
I swore to my comrade Odysseus that I would defend Atlantis with my life.

Chiron:
Now come at me, if you dare!

Jason:
Well said! Then let's settle this once and for all!

Jason:
...Good luck, you two!

Mash:
Jason!?

Jason:
I'm rooting for you! That'll have to be enough!

Fujimaru 1:
That's good enough for me!

Fujimaru 2:
Let's do this, Mash!

Mash:
...

Mash:
Right. Sorry about that, Captain Jason! I understand the situation now! Don't worry, we can handle this!

Mash:
Between Master Fujimaru and myself...

Mash:
...we're ready and willing to bring this Atlantis campaign to an end!

Chiron:
Have at you!

--BATTLE--

P.A. System:
Rebooting... Impossible.
Target elimination... Impossible.

P.A. System:
Logic unit... Inoperable. Weapon control systems...
Ninety-nine percent destroyed.

P.A. System:
Rebooting... Rebooting... Rebooting... SYSTEM ERROR
Rebooting... ERROR. System purge... Impossible.

P.A. System:
Backup systems... Inoperable.
Francis Drake... Lost.

P.A. System:
Emotion unit moral/ethical safeguards inoperable. Sending distress signal to Olympus... ERROR. Damage sustained to all units... Over ninety percent.

P.A. System:
Unit connection system error. CPU overload-induced freezing... Six hundred eighteen seconds. Time to complete system failure... One hundred seconds.

P.A. System:
...D... D-d... Damn you, Chaldea. Damn you, humans.
Damn you, Proper Human History...!

P.A. System:
Body...destroyed... Time to...total shutdown... No...
Gods can't die... Gods can't die! Gods can't die!

Jason:
That's one hell of a conniption. But it looks like it's almost over.

P.A. System:
Searching memory unit...

Chiron:
So this is it...

Chiron:
But...how did I lose?
No... How did you all win?

Chiron:
You should never have even had a chance...
We outmatched you in every possible sense...

Chiron:
Not just in numbers. I'm certain we were far stronger than you...

Jason:
True, I get where you're coming from.

Jason:
I can't speak for the other times, but while Heracles might have taken the Cerberi on his own this time...

Jason:
...the rest of the Servants never could have beaten them without ganging up and fighting them all at once.

Jason:
Even Achilles wasn't at his best, thanks to his heel being shot.

Jason:
I'd say Orion was the closest thing we had to a decent fighter.

Chiron:
That only makes the question more urgent.
How did you do it?

Jason:
That's the thing, Chiron.
There is no clear answer to that question.

Jason:
All we had going for us was our will to succeed.

Jason:
We were determined to win no matter what, and we swore to keep on going even when things seemed hopeless.

Jason:
You lot, on the other hand, had everything going for you.

Jason:
It was almost like you'd been preparing for a wholly different enemy to show up at some point.

Jason:
And above all, you had the peace of mind of knowing you were on the side of the gods.

Jason:
From where I stand, I'd say that was your side's biggest failing.

Chiron:
Hmm. I'm not sure I buy that...but I suppose it is one way of thinking about the issue.

Jason:
I see you're still just as much of a sore loser as ever!

Holmes:
Hurry! We just got a transmission from Nemo!

Nemo:
That was a great frontline operation.
Well done, all of you.

Nemo:
But I'm afraid the celebrations will have to wait.

Nemo:
As I suspected, Poseidon's whole body is starting to break down now that his cores have all been destroyed.

Nemo:
So you need to get back to the Storm Border as soon as possible. I'll hold back and wait for you as long as I can.

Mash:
U-understood!
Let's hurry, Master!

Mash:
You too, Jason!

Jason:
Hm? Oh, no thanks. I'm good here.
Besides, I'm exhausted.

Mash:
...

Fujimaru 1:
...Are you sure?

Jason:
...Yeah, I'm sure. The next time you summon me, make sure it's nooothing like this whole mess!

Jason:
Ugh, I'm seriously exhausted!
I'm never doing this kind of thing ever again!

Jason:
Go on, get out of here!
Let me get some rest already!

Fujimaru 1:
Jason!

Jason:
What?

Jason:
...Can you let go of me now?
Besides, you have a boat to catch.

Fujimaru 1:
Thank you!

Jason:
Will you stop it already? I've heard more than enough praise for one materialization. Go on, shoo.

Mash:
Jaso–Master?

Fujimaru 1:
See you again someday!!!

Jason:
...

G：Jason:
Ugh...
I seriously thought I was done for.

Chiron:
...Heh.

Chiron:
I never would have guessed that you were even closer to death than I am.

Chiron:
How did you fool everyone?

G：Jason:
Some stupid woman sent me a useless Mystic Code
that's only good for making you look like something you're not.

G：Jason:
...Well, I guess it did turn out to be more useful than I expected.

Chiron:
Is that what you used when you were devising your plan of attack?

G：Jason:
Sure was. I bet it made me look like a real accomplished tactician to them, too.

G：Jason:
They had no idea I was actually sweating bullets the entire time.

Chiron:
...I see. Fascinating.

Chiron:
I never knew that heroes who refuse to rely on the gods require such desperate measures to maintain their reputation.

G：Jason:
Ugh, just shut up and die already, would you?

Chiron:
No... While death would certainly be a merciful release from this pain, I've already suffered enough defeat.

Chiron:
So I think it would be much more interesting for you to teach me, your ostensible teacher in Proper Human History, a few things before we disappear.

G：Jason:
Ha. And here I thought you didn't have a sense of humor.

Chiron:
I still have trouble conceiving of a world devoid of gods.

Chiron:
Are humans truly able to survive in such a world?

G：Jason:
Sure they are. You yourself taught them a whole bunch of things about living life without any gods.

G：Jason:
...Not that I remembered more than half of them back when I was alive.

Chiron:
It seems our ways of life are just too different.

G：Jason:
You can say that again.

G：Jason:
That said...it looks like neither of us will die with any regrets. Don't you think?

Chiron:
Yes...you may...be right.

Chiron:
You know...now that you mention it...

Jason:
...

Chiron:
...

--ARROW--

Mash:
Mash Kyrielight and Fujimaru,
returning from battle.

Goredolf:
Good! Then let's go!
Wait. Where's Jason? Isn't he with you?

Mash:
Jason–

Fujimaru 1:
I think Jason deserves to rest now.

Goredolf:
...I see. Well, I suppose he did overexert himself a tad.

Goredolf:
I mean, he was only a third-rate Servant to begin with.
I can't say I blame him for wanting to rest.

Goredolf:
Very well, permission for leave granted!
Now let's get back to the Storm Border!

Goredolf:
Come on, come on, come on!
There, I see it!

Da Vinci:
I'll guide you there! Keep heading
right into the Storm Border's docking bay!

P.A. System:
...Dra...ke...
...Cursed...human...

P.A. System:
...Zeus... Atlantis has...been breached...
I'm afraid the rest...is up to you...

Nemo:
All right, let's go.

Nemo:
I know we've lost a lot of good Servants,
but we've still got something valuable.

Nemo:
We've made it this far alive.

Holmes:
Quite so.

Holmes:
Every hero we encountered on this journey had to sacrifice themselves so that we could reach this point.

Holmes:
The option to rest in peace beside them is not one we can avail ourselves of.

Fujimaru 1:
...Let's go!

Mash:
Right!

Goredolf:
Hm?

Goredolf:
Is it just me, or is there an odd sound coming from the ceiling in addition to the floor shaking?

Goredolf:

Goredolf:
(Glance)

Goredolf:
Wah!!!

Da Vinci:

Fujimaru 1:
Whoa!!!

Holmes:
My apologies for interrupting when you all appear to be having difficulties with your vocabulary...

Holmes:

Holmes:
Captain, if we don't do something soon, I'm afraid that water is going to collide with the ship's dorsal section.

Nemo:
...All right. Prepare to fire anti-ship missiles!
Entering data now!

Nemo:
Our target is Poseidon's hull. We need to destroy him as soon as possible so we can brace for descent!

Nemo:
Target the missiles far enough away that the detonations won't harm us.

Goredolf:
Aaaaaah! So much shakiiing!
Both the ship and my stomaaach!

Holmes:

There, he's collapsed!
Begin descent!

Master! Give me your hand!

Fujimaru 1:
Mash!

Mash:
Come on! We're finally almost to Olympus!

Goredolf:
Aaaaaah! We're falliiing!!!
I don't wanna diiieee!!!

Nemo:
Don't worry, nobody's going to die. Well, this might hurt enough for you to wish you were dead...

Goredolf:
That's not reassuring at aaall!!!

Fujimaru 1:
Is everyone all right?

Nemo:
I'm okay...
All hands, status report.

Nemo Engineer:
This is the engine room. Of course we're okay.
I'm the one running this joint, remember?

Nemo Professor:
Professor here. Everyone in the second division is fine, too.

Nemo Professor:
Though I did bump my head something fierce...
(Sniff)

Nemo Baker:
Hi there! This is the lovely lunch lady down in the cafeteria♡ Everyone's yummy food is still nice and yummy!

Holmes:
I-I'm all right, too. Though I daresay, I haven't felt so intoxicated in quite some time...

Da Vinci:
Hey, hey! Computer room here.
I'd say I'm...hanging in there, I guess?

Da Vinci:
I don't think I'm malfunctioning or anything...
but I am feeling kind of tuckered out...

Mash:
I'm fine too.
And so is Fou.

Fou:
Fooou!

Holmes:
At any rate, we have, at long last, arrived at our destination: the home base of the fifth Lostbelt.

Holmes:
This is where Kirschtaria Wodime, leader of the Crypters, awaits.

Holmes:
See for yourselves. Though you may find it difficult to believe what your eyes report.

Goredolf:
...

Nemo:
...He's so shocked he fainted.
Not that I can blame him.

Da Vinci:
It really does feel like...we've wandered into the land of the gods.

Mash:
So this is the Interstellar Mountainous City...

Fujimaru 1:
Olympus!

--SECTION BREAK--

Narration:
She entrusted the Chaldeans' lives to the sea,
as the first of their guides.

Narration:
She took advantage of her own cursed body to cause havoc among enemy forces.

Narration:
She fought back as hard as she could, even if it meant discarding everything but her ability to kill.

Narration:
He accomplished in death something he never managed in life: bringing hope to the world.

Narration:
He never stopped running, even after his crippling wound.

Narration:
He answered a summon to buy them just a bit of time, and in doing so, gave them hope.

Narration:
He vowed to do everything he could to help his trusted friend.

Narration:
He chose to sacrifice himself to help them without a moment's hesitation, because it was the right thing to do.

Narration:
He loved the moon, and brought her down to save her.

Narration:
He saw everything, fought for everything,
and saw everyone off when he was done.

Narration:
And in the wake of all their great deeds, there is now nothing and no one left in this sea.

Narration:
And so, Atlantis was breached. What awaits Chaldea now is a grand, glorious, subterranean city.

--SECTION BREAK--

Musashi:
Hm, that shining star up in the night sky...!
That's got to be the Chaldeans' ship!

Musashi:
Hah! You see? I told you they'd make it here!

Musashi:
I'll admit I was a little worried, but I always trusted they'd pull through! I'm so proud of them!

Musashi:
...Nope, I can't do it. That's a little too much fake cheer, even for me.

Musashi:
I wish I could go meet up with them now, but it's just not that simple. Not when this place is even more brutal than Atlantis.

Musashi:
I knew we were in for a tough fight when I got here, but this is still way worse than I was expecting...

Musashi:
Oh well, it's not like I've got any other choice now!

Musashi:
All right, since this hideout looks to be deserted too, I think I'll go check out the next one!

--SECTION BREAK--

Senji Muramasa:
...

???:
Magnificent.

Senji Muramasa:
Ha. Stop that.

Senji Muramasa:
You might not be from my country, but you're still a god of the forge. It's embarrassing, having you judge my work.

Hephaestus:
That spirit of yours is what is so magnificent.

Hephaestus:
A true blacksmith transcends good and evil.
All they seek is to create.

Senji Muramasa:
I wouldn't know anything about that.

Senji Muramasa:
All I know is, now that I've been summoned, I've gotta make what the customer wants.

Senji Muramasa:
Even if what I make ends up being used to destroy my own world.

Hephaestus:
Are you unhappy about that?

Senji Muramasa:
Does it matter?

Senji Muramasa:
I've got a job to do as a Servant, so that's what I'm gonna do. End of story.

Senji Muramasa:
'Sides, you've got your own troubles to worry about.

Senji Muramasa:
It's not like you planned on my cutting you down being the catalyst that got you back in working order, after all.

Hephaestus:
I was originally going to be destroyed, Muramasa...
And you protected me.

Hephaestus:
My Atlantis self's logic led to him siding with Proper Human History. Now, I'm choosing to side with Olympus.

Hephaestus:
But, even so... I would still like your help.

Senji Muramasa:
...Fine. Long as it's something I can do.
